title: Forget trivial 'Piegate', the FA should have focused on disciplining shameful Wenger for undermining authorities
text:
Sport Opinion Forget trivial 'Piegate', the FA should have focused on disciplining shameful Wenger for undermining authorities At the same time as Wayne Shaw faces an investigation over eating a pie, it was revealed just what Wenger said to Anthony Taylor after the Arsenal boss managed to weasel his way out of a stadium ban Share Arsene Wenger clashes with fourth official Anthony Taylor before being sent to the stands (Photo: REUTERS) Share Get   
Twenty-three-stone goalkeepers making a few quid on the side is old hat. 
When William Henry ‘Fatty’ Foulke’s best days between the sticks were behind him, one tale has it that he resorted to becoming a ‘Beat the Goalie’ attraction on Blackpool’s seafront. 
Fatty was a fine keeper, won two FA Cup winners’ medals, was bought for £50 in 1905 by Chelsea and had his own issues with the Football Associaton. 
At the end of the 1902 FA Cup Final, Fatty, stark naked, pursued referee Tom Kirkham, who took refuge in a broom cupboard. 
Fatty, then playing for Sheffield United, had been upset by a Southampton equaliser. Wayne Shaw tucks into a pie (Photo: REUTERS) Sutton substitute goal keeper Wayne Shaw and manager Paul Doswell (Photo: PA) 
If true, he should have been disciplined but, presumably, the FA just laughed at Fatty, just as they should have laughed at Wayne Shaw . Or, preferably, ignored him. 
That they gave his tawdry stunt the oxygen of publicity by ‘investigating’ it sums them up. Clueless at times. 
Look into the issue of football and gambling by all means, while all the time having a bookmaking partner of your own of course, but this was just a stupid stunt. 
Anyone with the merest smidgeon of betting knowledge knows this was nothing to do with dodgy gambling, this was no type of coup. It was just a gimmick. End of story. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Sutton United goalkeeper confirms he did not bet on himself eating a pie Share this video Watch Next 
The bookie concerned said it cost them a five-figure sum. My guess is that the five-figure sum was £125.75p. Tops. 
The chances of anyone making any shady money out of Shaw’s pie-eating were slimmer than Arsene Wenger , in the adjacent dugout, tucking into a meat and potato while trying to do up his zip. 
There is a reason every bookie smokes a fat cigar - and it’s not taking lumps of money on a man eating food. 
But talking of Wenger, it was a good moment for the FA to bury bad news. Wenger on the sidelines at Sutton (Photo: Stuart MacFarlane) 
At a similar time as the FA’s investigation into Shaw’s prattish antics was announced, the written reasons for Wenger’s pathetic four-match technical area ban were being released. 
He had told match officials to ‘**** off’, accused one of being ‘dishonest’ and shoved the same person. Twice. 
If the FA were serious about getting really tough with managers’ misbehaviour, they would have appealed the independent commission’s verdict on Wenger. But they didn’t. 
Is there a more heinous thing than a manager to do than to accuse an official of being ‘dishonest’? Taking a bite out of a savoury snack, maybe. Wenger is sent to the stands by Jon Moss (Photo: Shaun Botterill) Arsene Wenger clashes with fourth official Anthony Taylor (Photo: REUTERS) 
Wenger and his lawyers managed to weasel their way out of a stadium suspension by, among other things, apologising, citing the misdemeanours of other managers and saying the shoves were the instinctive reaction of feeling his personal space was being invaded. Shameful, just shameful. 
Repeat. He accused an official of being dishonest. 
Wenger questioned the integrity of a man who earns less in a year than he does in a week. And the FA were happy with a punishment that saw him sit in the posh seats for a few games and shell out short change. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
